string-array.name: Panchanandapur_Ferry_Ghat_GWB
string-array.item: It is on the bank of the Ganges in Malda District, WB. Though underdeveloped it is market place. The main stream of the Ganges is 500 mtr away from it. Due to silt an island has been formed in between main stream and sub stream. Hundreds of motorized boats ply every day transportation of goods and people from WB to Bihar. Stone chips are carried by big motorised Boats from Bihar to the ghat from where it is carried to different part of Malda and surrounding districts for construction work.

string-array.name: Armenian_Ferry_Ghat_HWB
string-array.item: It was built in 1734 by Manvel Hazaar Maliyan, a celebrated Calcutta trader of Armenian origin. This elegant ferry Ghat was just one of the many contributions made by the benevolent Armenian toward developing Calcutta’s infrastructure and sociocultural rapport. Well maintained and clean Ghat beside Chotelal Ki Ghat. Nice for photography sessions with the scenic Rabindra Setu (Howrah Bridge) and Howrah Station on the opposite banks of the river Hooghly. Nearby Mallick Ghat Flower Market.
Golabari Armenian Ferry Service, Armenian Howrah Station Ferry Service, Bus service, Taxi Service, Near Howrah Tram Depot. Nearby Railway Station - Howrah Junction, B.B.D. Bag

string-array.name: Babughat_HWB
string-array.item: Strand Rd, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700021

The ghat has a tall colonial structure, which is the landing berth of the ghat. It is a fine Doric-Greek style pavilion with huge pillars. The ghat, originally known was Baboo Raj Chandra Ghat, is now only known by first words Baboo-ghat or Babu-ghat. Babu / Baboo in Bengali means Sahib or gentleman. The ghat is named after Babu Raj Chandra Das, husband of Rani Rashmoni and zamindar of Janbazar, who built it in 1830, in memory of her late husband. A marble tablet beneath the pediment implies that some of the credit for the erection of the ghat must go to Lord William Bentinck as he encouraged such spending with a view to improve public amenities. It is second oldest ghat of Kolkata. Close to Eden Gardens and Netaji Indoor Stadium. Close to Calcutta High Court. Near Millenium Park. Neighbour ghats - West Bengal Tourist Jetty, Outram Ghat
Ramkrishnapur Babughat Ferry Service, Babughat Howrah Station Ferry Service, Babughat Bus Stand, Cab, Taxi, Auto, Horse Carts available

string-array.name: Nimtala_Ghat_Crematorium_HWB
string-array.item: Strand Bank Rd, Ahiritola, Jorabagan, Kolkata, West Bengal 700006

The burning ghat was constructed in 1827. In 2010 the central government of India upgraded the crematorium at a cost of INR ₹140 million (US$2.0 million). The Bengali polymath Rabindranath Tagore was cremated here in 1941. The Rabindranath Tagore Memorial in the crematorium compound was beautified as part of the 2010 project. The ghat has also been represented in popular literature. It plays a significant part in the plot of the 2013 Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award winning Malayalam novel, Aarachaar, by K. R. Meera.
Bus service available, Closest Railway Station – Bara Bazar

string-array.name: Nishadraj_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

The presence of sailors on the banks of the river is also associated with the culture of the river. They have a different culture on the waves of rivers. The role of Nishad Raj Guhaya in the story of crossing the Ganges to Lord Rama in the Treta Yuga and a unique example of his devotion, faith and devotion are still given today. The Nishad Ghat built on the banks of the Ganges, dedicated to the same society in Kashi, is also known as the Nishad Raj Ghat. Before the year 1980, it used to be the uncovered raw part of Prahlad Ghat. Which in 1988, with the cooperation of the state government, the irrigation department gave a separate identity by constructing concrete. Due to the abundance of Nishad Mallah people in the Ghat area, it got its name as Nishad Raj Ghat. However the number of temples on the banks of the ghat is almost negligible. Although presently the ghat remains fixed, the devotees and local people visiting this ghat also take bath at Prahlada Ghat, which is known earlier. Although people also clean clothes etc. at this ghat. But due to the existence associated with Prahlad Ghat, it gets the same value. Also, this ghat is also included in various events related to Ganga. Earlier it changed into a part of Prabhu Ghat till first half 20th century. Now a massive quantity of boatmen with their small boat and nets can be seen listen. Ghat has one Nishad raj Temple which in truth become constructed by way of boatmen families just a few year again. This Ghat has been built by the Municipal Corporation. Varanasi in the Ganges financial institution made numerous stunning ferries, those ferries are related in a few legendary or spiritual narrative.
Devotees are taking bathtub within the early morning to be unfastened from all the sins and prepare themselves for the Pooja. Sailor is pulling his boat to carry it on the financial institution that allows you to take pilgrims from one bank to the other. Pilgrims within the orange get dressed are taking their breakfast after the bathtub at the Gange ghat with a purpose to use their full day for seeing the attractive scenes. Some of them are taking tub and some of them are carrying cloth.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Raj_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Rabindranath Tagore Rd, Near Sant Ravidas Mandir, Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

This Ghat is one of the least commercialised ghats.... mostly used by local people for daily chores...good place to sit and relax. Situated near to Kashi railway station, this is one of the famous ghats of Varanasi. This is next to Raj Ghat bridge. Famous Ravidas temple is located on this ghat. It is also famous for pind daan and asthi-visarjan. Famous priests of Kashi are based here. The ghats can easily be accessed through any kind of vehicles and parking facilities are also available here. This ghat is also friendly for disabled people who can not walk through narrow lanes of Kashi. They can easily reach here by car or bike. The ghat was transformed with levelling and some built structure by means of Rajirao Balaji in ca 1720. This changed into rebuilt with stone slabs by way of Amrit Rao Peshva for the duration of 1780-1807, who changed into living in Banaras as exiled via the British government. Amrit Rao has also constructed the four temples of Amriteshvara, Vinayakeshvara, Narayaneshvara and Gangeshvara, and four auxiliary shrines, and additionally renovated the Prabhasha Tirtha in 1780. Earlier the ghat turned into called Amritarao Ghat as referred via James Prinsep and Edwin Greeves, however this turned into described below the call of “Raja Ghat” by way of Motichand. The northern aspect is the palace, and the southern element is the Annapurna Math. These sections are divided via the stairway. Till 1980 there was a culture to feed Brahmins, Sanskrit college students, ascetics, etc. But whilst the Intach commenced its programme and the Clarks Hotel took initiated to use it for promoting a special group of tourists, the earlier traditions vanished. In 1965 the Government of Uttar Pradesh has renovated this ghat and built the stairs made of purple stones. At the principle front location, a refectory is constructed that completely reserved for the Brahmins.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Rani_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Well maintained and well decorated ghat. Ferries are available for a ride across river Ganga. Well maintained sitting arrangement and bathing arrangement for tourist. The place is well connected with main road but vehicles is not permitted as connecting roads with main road is too narrow. The matter is in the year 1988 when the irrigation department in collaboration with the state government built another Ganga Ghat. Earlier this ghat was raw and used to be a part of Rajghat itself. Even earlier, in 1937, a huge building named Janaki Kunj was built on top of the ghat by Rani Muniya Sahiba of Itauja, Lucknow. After which this ghat became known as Rani Ghat. At present the ghat is firm but due to lack of special religious importance, the bathing work here is relatively less than all other ghats. Therefore, there is a large gathering of cloth cleaners at the ghat. However, the order of special and other events related to Ganga at the Ghat continues.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Telianala_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Domari, Uttar Pradesh 221001
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Sakka_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: A3/119, Trilochan Bazar, Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Domari, Uttar Pradesh 221001

The correct name was Shuka Ghat but by the time of disrespect, it became Sakka Ghat. In 1988, with the cooperation of the state government, the irrigation department built a concrete building on the ghat, which gave it an important charm and identity. The Ghats are mentioned by James the British historian James Prinsep in a citation in 1822. While Wax, who was almost his contemporary, discussed it in the year 1868 as Babu Suka Ghat. However, in the midst of all these naming discrepancies, it is popular today among the locals as Sakka Ghat. Sant Hardas Ram Sevashram is located in the upper part of the Ghat. Bal Chandreshwar Shiva temple is in its premises. At present, the ghats are firm, but due to the cleaning of the cloth by the dhobis, the arrival of the devotees and devotees to this ghat is also less. But all the major events related to Ganga are also held at this ghat.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Trilochan_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Near Gaay Ghat, Maidagin, Ghats Of Varanasi, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

One of the decent ghat on the eastern side, lanes above the ghat gives great exposure for street photographers, also there is a vyamsala (gym) right at the ghat upstairs, do check it out and walk through very narrow lanes typical banaras type. Wrestlers may give some nice portraiture. In 1740, Narayan Dixit built a ghatka with the help of Peshwas. Since the Trilochan Mahadev Temple is located in the Ghat area, it has since been called Trilochan Ghat. According to Kashikhand, this temple is dedicated to the third eye of Shiva. According to local Brahmins and priests, the rivers Narmada and Pippila meet in an invisible form in the Ganges on this coast. These three rivers are similar to the three eyes of Shiva, hence the Ghat is named Trilochan Ghat. This ghat is one of the best pilgrimages of Kashi, which is mentioned from the time of Gahadwal. The Trilochan temple at the Ghat was destroyed during time of Aurangzeb. Which was built by Nathubala Peshwa of Poona in the eighteenth century. This temple was rebuilt by Ramadevi in 1965. Was built. Trilochan Mahadev is the principal deity of the Omkareshwar shrine of Kashi. The pilgrims who visit Omkareshwar begin their journey at the Ghat only after bathing and worshiping Trilochan Mahadev. The position of Pippila and Trivishtapa shrine in the Ganges in front of the ghat has been considered. Vaishakh Shukla Tritiya or Akshaya Tritiya is the annual decoration of Trilochan Mahadev. On this occasion, people take a darshan of Trilochan Shiva after bathing at the ghat and religious-cultural activities like bhajan-kirtan, satsang etc. are organized at the ghat. In addition to the Trilochan temple, Panchakshwar Shiva, Kotishwar Shiva, Uddandmund Vinayak, The temple of Yamuneshwar Shiva etc. is established. Arunaditya Surya is worshiped in the Dwadash Adityas of Kashi. The steps of this ghat are also built in classical legislation. The garrison has been constructed after twelve steps. These twelve steps are considered as the symbol of Shiva. Presently the ghat is clean and clean. Bathing at the ghat is of special importance in the month of Vaishakh. Due to religious significance, local bathing as well as outdoor bathing are also visited here. In the year 1965, the state government had repaired the ghat; in the east the southern part of the ghat was raw, which was newly constructed in 1988 by the Irrigation Department in collaboration with the state government.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Gaay_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Maidagin, Near Trilochar Ghat, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

Good neat and clean Washroom is also available there. Changing rooms are available but they are dirty and not in condition for use so there is problem of changing room for ladies. In the nineteenth century the southern part of the Ghat was built by Naresh Rana Shamsher Bahadur of Nepal and the northern part was built by Balabai Shitole, wife of Diwan Malavji Narasimha Rao Shitole of Gwalior Dynasty. It is believed that bathing at the ghat provides freedom from the sin of killing cow. For this reason, the ghat was named Cow Ghat. Whereas the local people believe that in ancient times people from the neighboring region used to visit this ghat to feed and bathe the cows. Probably because of this it is named. The authenticity of the Ghat related photographs obtained from Sawai Mansingh II Museum also proves its authenticity. According to Lingpuran and Kashikhand, the position of Gopraksh Tirtha in front of the Ghat has been considered. After bathing in a pilgrimage, there is a special significance for the worship of Mukhirmirmalika Gauri. Mukha Nirmalika Gauri occupies a prominent position among the newcomers of Kashi. Hanuman, in addition to Mukha Nirmalika Gauri, Shitala, Laxminarayan, Shiva Temple, Dalmia Bhawan is established in the ghat area. The huge palace built by the King of Nepal in the southern part of the ghat was occupied by industrialist Dalmia in 1940. Mother of Dalmia, Kashi used to live in this palace. This palace is currently known as Dalmia Bhavan. In the northern part, there are tenants now living in the huge building built by Balabai Shitole. There are many Shiva lingas on the steps of the ghat and the statue of Nandi seated made of stone is also about three feet high. Many religious-cultural events are organized at the Ghat, including the Mundan rites, marriage, Ganga Pujaiya pindadan and bhajan-kirtan, music, organized on the annual makeup of temples. Ramlila held during the month of Kartik is special. At present, the ghat is clean and strong, the daily ghat comes to the ghat as well as those who bathe at a special festival. According to the local people, people come from far and wide to come here and perform bathing, worship and rituals at the ghat to get rid of cow-killing sins. In 1965 the ghat was repaired by the state government.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Sheetala_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Beside Ganga River, near Bundi Parkota Ghat, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

Famous for Big sheetla temple here nearest Dashaswamedh ghat both are parallel to the straight lines of the banking of Ganga river such that devoties come here to see the Ganga Arti and worship to mata sheetla blessed that who will adandence on the door of mata is peaceful goddess in forms of Durga. She worshipped every apart of India has full devotion of Hindu religion belonging only the festival of Navaratri are the major rolled of the many kinds of worship presented to see here. Never traveled here very excited with Basant and sarad Navaratricelebrated with more amazing performance. Even today, the locals consider it part of Dashashwamedhghat. It is believed that in the beginning of the eighteenth century, Queen Ahilyabai Holkar of the princely state of Indore of Madhya Pradesh reconstructed the ghat and in its form, made many works for the convenience of the devotees, which made it very convenient for those coming from far flung places. Earlier this part used to come under Dashashwamedh Ghat. But a few years after the construction of the Ghat, the Shitala Mata Temple was established here. Whose name was later changed to Sheetla Ghat, which is still known by that name. The Shitala temple holds special recognition because of its architecture. In Chaitra and Shardiya Navratri, there is a crowd of believers here, people pray for charity by bathing and donating at the ghat itself. Although there is a crowd of people throughout the year, but there is a large crowd in religious events, especially at the ghat. The ghat itself is believed to carry out various rites associated with various Hindu religions. Devdeepavali and Ganga Dussehra along with other major events also take place at the ghat. The process of visiting tourists and pilgrims from all over the country goes on throughout the year. The state government also constructed here after independence in order to protect the ghats. However, construction has been done from time to time to give the Ghat a grand appearance. The order of people coming to the ghat on beliefs remains the same throughout the year, but the sequence of various religious rituals related to Sheetla Ashtami and Mata Sheetla continues throughout the year.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Bundi_Parkota_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Beside Ganga River, Near Panchganga Ghat, Maidagin, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

At the end of the sixteenth century, Bundi, Rajasthan, Maharaja Rao Surjan built a huge palace situated on the ghat and ghat. According to Girvan Padmanjari, the ancient name of the Ghat was Adi Visheshwar Ghat. In the middle of the palace situated in the Ghat is the temple of Vishveshwar Shiva, due to which the name of the Ghat was named as Adi Vishveshwar Ghat. Formerly it extended to the present Shitalaghat II. In the nineteenth century, Raja Rao Pritam Singh of Bundi rebuilt the Shitla Ghat II in the nineteenth century, after which the ghat was divided into Pritam Singh and Sheetla Ghats respectively. After the repair of both the ghats by the state government in 1958, Pritam Singh Ghat was renamed to Bundi Parkota Ghat after belonging to Bundi kings. Apart from Adi Vishweshwar, Annapurna, Seshamadhav, Vishnu and Karnaditya Surya, The temple is established in the form of Aditya. The position of the Karnaditya shrine in the Ganges in front of the Ghat has been considered. Although the ghat is sure, one has to go through the steps of Sheetla Ghat to reach Gangahat. Therefore, the local people do not bathe on this ghat and do bathing work on the Sheetla Ghat itself, but the remains of artistic pillars and carvings of the palace can still be seen. Whereas all the major religious events related to Ganga are also organized at this ghat.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Brahma_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Maidagin Crossing, near Panchganga Ghat, Ghats of varanasi, VNS, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

In the year 1740, Narayan Dixit built this ghat along with Durgaghat. The Ghat is first mentioned in Givarna Padmanjari. There is a legend about the naming of the Ghat that when Brahma Ji arrived in Kashi on the orders of Shiva, Brahma Ji made this Ghat his place of residence. That is why this ghat came to be called Brahmaghat. The relation of Brahma and Kashi is also mentioned in the Matyasya Purana. The Brahma temple on the ghat dates back to the 13th century. The statue of Brahma is installed here and the Brahmeshwar Shiva temple is located. Bindu Madhav, inside the Sri Kashi Math Institute located on the Ghat itself Dattatreya and Laxmi Narsingh Temple are established. The position of Bhairav shrine in the Ganges in front of the ghat has been considered. Different steps for going from Gangahat to Brahmeshwar Shiva temple and Brahma temple are built according to classical legislation. After five steps to reach Brahmeshwar Shiva, the outpost has been constructed, which is the symbol of Panchayatan Shiva. At the same time, after the four steps up to the Brahma temple, the outpost has been constructed, which can be considered a symbol of the quadriplegic Brahma. According to beliefs, Adi Shakracharya used to reside in Shri Kashimath Institute on the arrival of Kashi. Chaturmas ritual is organized by Kachikotti Shakaracharya at this ghat every year. Presently the ghats are clean and strong. Local people do bathing work here. The Ghat was rebuilt by the state government in 1958.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Panchganga_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: 7/111, Sonarpura Rd, Ghats of varanasi, Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

At a distance of 1.5 km from Manikarnika Ghat and 7 km from Varanasi Junction, Panchganga Ghat is another popular ghat along the banks of River Ganga in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh. It is one of the cleanest ghats in Varanasi and among the popular Varanasi Tourist Places.
Panchganga Ghat is called so because it is built at the confluence of five holy rivers - Ganga, Saraswati, Dhupapapa, Yamuna and Kirana. Out of these five only Ganga remains visible while the other four are believed to have disappeared in earth. There are five black stone idols residing here for the five river goddesses. Many devotees throng to this ghat in hopes of attaining blessings from these five goddesses.
This ghat has lot of history. It is believed that Panchganga Ghat is also served as a teaching place for Vaidant Ramanand, the Guru of great saint Kabir. Further, it is also believed that the saint poet Tulsi Das composed the famous Vinay-Patrika here at this ghat.
This ghat is popular for Alamgir Mosque which is believed to have been constructed by Aurangzeb. Also known as Beni Madhav-ka-Darera, the mosque is believed to be constructed on the site of Bindu Madhava Temple erected by the Maratha chieftain Beni Madhav Rao Scindia in the 17th century AD. The temple was destroyed and the Mosque was constructed at that place during Mughal invasion in India. This imposing Hindu and Persian architectural structure, designed with carved pillars, turrets and marvelous domes, showcase the rich artworks of ancient India. As the name suggests, Panchganga Ghat is the place where five sacred rivers converge to form an overwhelming spectacle of beauty and holiness. The five holy rivers are the Ganges, Saraswati, Yamuna, Kirana and Dhupapapa. The Panchganga Ghat stands as an example of Hindu-Muslim harmony. The Mosque of Alamgir, also known as Beni Madhav-ka-Darera, stands tall near the ghat on a site where it is believed stood the Bindu Madhava Temple.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Jatar_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Ghats of varanasi, Ram Ghat, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

Jatar Ghat is adjacent to the Panchganga Ghat in the vibrant city of Benares. While the kings constructed the pucca construction on the ghats, the competition for pucca construction on the ghat has been equal in their courts. Balaji Jatar, considered the Diwan of King Jeevaji Rao, was built in the early nineteenth century of Gwalior in the order of the Ghats by identification and identification with the Ghats. His identity became permanent as Jatar Ghat. The British historian James Prinsep in Varanasi has also mentioned in the history sequence in the introduction of the Ghats of Kashi. Near Balaji Ghat close to Ghat There is an ancient temple of Laxminarayan. Which is considered to be a unique example of glass art of its own way. Some major pilgrimage is recognized near this ghat on the banks of Ganges, although it is not more authentic. But on the basis of recognition, the order of people coming and worshiping remains. Earlier the Ghat was quite neglected, but after administrative assistance, the Ghat was recognized after the renovation in the eighties and the procession of devotees started here. There is not much recognition of the ghat but in all the major events related to the Ganges, this ghat is also buzzing. In the eighties, the ghat got recognition after renovation and the order of devotees started here. There is not much recognition of the ghat but in all the major events related to the Ganges, this ghat is also buzzing. string-array.name: Naya_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

This become and vintage web site of Yajnesvara Ghat and became made pucca by using Swami Maheshwarananda in mid nineteenth century. In the closeby stream lies the Visala Gaja Tirtha. Phuta Ghat is one a number of the numerous ghats at the banks of Ganges at Varanasi. It become in the beginning called Yajneshvara Ghat. Phuta Ghat was renovated and rebuilt by a respected person named Swami Maheshvarananda in mid-19th century. Therefore the ghat is also referred to as Naya Ghat, in which the phrase ‘naya’ approach ‘new.’ Ghats in Varanasi are riverfront steps leading to the banks of the River Ganges. Most of the ghats are bathing and puja ceremony ghats, even as ghats are used completely as cremation websites. The set of stairs lead all the way down to some thing as small as a pond or as big as a chief river. The time period ghat refers to a sequence of steps leading right down to a frame of water, mainly a holy river.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Bhonsale_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Near Ganga Mahal Gate, Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

In 1780, Maratha king Bhonsale of Nagpur made this ghat and as a result named after him. Two crucial shrines nearby Bhonsale Ghat are Yameshwara temple and Yamaditya temple. This ghat is another instance of contributions of Maratha rulers to the very lifeline of Varanasi. One of critical ghats at the Ganges River in Varanasi, was constructed via the Maratha ruling family of Nagpur. Since the Maratha rulers of Nagpur belonged to the Bhonsle Family, the ghat got here to be called Bhonsala Ghat.
The ghat changed into repaired and renovated in 1795. Lakshminarayan Temple, Yameshwar Temple and Yamaditya Temple are the primary shrines on this ghat. The different looking Bhosale Ghat become constructed by means of the Maratha ruling circle of relatives of Nagpur, who belonged to the Bhosale family. It is a sizeable stone constructing with small creative home windows at the top. The term ghat refers to a series of steps main down to a body of water, especially a holy river.

string-array.name: Ganga_Mahal_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Near Antique, Ghats of varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

Ganga Mahal Ghat is named after a palation building of ex. Maharaja of Banaras to wards the north cease of Assi Ghat. Infact Ghat has a little cultural significance besides the Beautiful carvings depiction the Rajput and nearby architectural grandeur of 16th century. Ganga Mahal Ghat is one of the principal ghats at the Ganges River in Varanasi. Constructed in 1830 CE through the Narayan dynasty, the ghat is north of Assi Ghat and turned into at first constructed as an extension to Assi Ghat.
The Narayan dynasty, in 1830, built a palace via the river Ganga in Varanasi. The palace become referred to as "Ganga Mahal". Since the Mahal become housed on the ghat, the ghat was named "Ganga Mahal Ghat". Stone steps between Assi Ghat and Ganga Mahal Ghat separates the 2 ghats. This palace homes the layout studio of Hemang Agrawal while the higher flooring are utilized by the "Indo-Swedish Study Centre" organised by way of Karlstad University.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.It is 6 kilometers south-east of Varanasi Junction railway station

string-array.name: Scindia_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Scindia Ghat is quite a picturesque and peaceful place, with none of the grimness of nearby Manikarnika Ghat (the burning ghat). Of particular interest is the partially submerged Shiva temple at the water edge. It sunk during the construction of the ghat in 1830. The narrow maze of alleyways above the ghat hides a number of Varanasi important temples. This area is called Siddha Kshetra and it attracts plenty of pilgrims It is one of the ghats in Varanasi and borders Manikarnika ghat a place of Hindu cremation, to the north. At this ghat, a tilted temple can be found lying partially submerged in the Ganga river and it is argued that this ghat collapsed under its own excessive weight. The ghat is named after the scindias, who built it in 1830. Above the ghat, several of kashi’s most influential shrines are located within the tight maze of alleys of Siddha Kshetra (Field of Fulfillment). According to mythology, agni(fire), the God of Fire, was born here. Hindu devotees propitiate at this place to Vireshwara, the Lord of all heroes, for a son. Scindia Ghat has Manikarnika Ghat on the north side. The ghat is located in Ghasi Tola of Varanasi. It is located just 1.2 km from Dashashwamedh Ghat if travelled through Tripura Bhairwi road. The ghat is located 7 km away from Banaras Hindu University. It is famous for the bathing on the ghat that who are joining the funeral work at Manikarnika ghat to burn the dead body of their relativities some times after all of take up both here but local public come down to the come for bath here for the worship of Shiva as Atmavisheswar sankatha ji 'pitambara Devi 'more God and godess temple on the top of banking Ganga. In the daily basis and his work schedule to her worshipped in same temple. On the top of banking details of the more temple as Atma viseswar'Dev guru brihaspati 'Maharajah yam 'Goddess sankatha Devi Pitambara'katyani'morherkali more shiv temple in narrow street in Vns.

string-array.name: Manikarnika_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Near Lalita Ghat, Ghats of varanasi, Lahori Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

One of the city oldest ghats, this iconic site is a storied spot for traditional Hindu cremations. It is one of the oldest ghats in Varanasi. The Manikarnika Ghat is mentioned in a Gupta inscription of 5th century.[4] It is revered in Hindu religion. When Mata Sati (Aadi shakti mata) sacrificed her life and set her body ablaze after Raja Daksh Prajapati (one of the sons of Lord Brahma) tried to humiliate Lord Shiva in a Yagya practiced by Daksh. Lord Shiva took her burning body to the Himalaya. On seeing the unending sorrow of Lord Shiva, Vishnu sends the Divine chakra to cut the body into 51 parts which fall on earth. They are called "Ekannya Shaktipeeth". Lord Shiva established Shakti Peeth wherever Sati body had fallen. At Manikarnika ghat, Mata Sati Ear ornament had fallen. To know that tourists come here to see the funeral pyres being set to fire in the open is more weird than fascinating. The routine ceremony starts when the dead body (wrapped in cloth) arrives and is carried on a bamboo stretcher with the chant ‘Ram naam satya hai’ echoing through the air. Next, the cost of cremation is calculated depending on the weight and type of the wood used. Sandalwood is the most expensive of all wood varieties available. The corpse is then dipped in the water of the River Ganges while the wood is stacked to build the pyre. Though photography is not allowed here, several tourists, especially foreigners, capture videos of the ghat or click pictures while on a boat tour of the city.
Auto, Cycle Rikshaw service available. Boating service available.

string-array.name: Lalita_Ghat_GUP
string-array.item: Near Meer Ghat, Ghats of varanasi, Lahori Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001

One of the main ghats on the Ganges River in Varanasi. The ghat is named after Hindu Goddess Lalita and was built in early 19th century by King of Nepal, Rana Bahadur Shah. The ghat houses the famous Nepali Mandir and Lalita Gauri Mandir. King of Nepal, Rana Bahadur Shah took exile in Varanasi from 1800 to 1804 and titled himself as "Swami Nirgunanda". During his exile, he decided to build a replica of Pashupatinath Temple in Varanasi. Construction of the temple commenced during his exile / stay in Varanasi. During the construction, Shah moved back to Nepal. On 25 April 1806, Rana Bahadur Shah was stabbed to death by his stepbrother, Sher Bahadur Shah. His son Girvan Yuddha Bikram Shah Deva undertook the construction of the temple (now called Nepali Mandir), a dharamshala and Lalita Ghat. The construction got over 20 years after the deadline. The ghat is named after Hindu Goddess Lalita. Goddess Lalita is one of the group of ten goddesses of Hindu belief, collectively called Mahavidyas or Dasha-Mahavidyas. She is the foremost and the most important in Dasha-Mahavidyas. All other Mahavidyas concludes in her vidya i.e. Sri Vidya. Her consort is Maha Kameswara. She is the highest aspect of Goddess Adi Shakti. Parvati is the complete incarnation of Lalita Maha Tripura Sundari. Affiliated to this site are the well known Lingam of Ganga Keshava; shrines of Gangatitya, Kashi Devi, Lalita Devi and Bhagirath Tirtha. It is a popular belief that a glimpse of Lalita Devi brings the same blessings as circumambulating the entire world. It is also believed that blessings of the Goddess Lalita eliminates problems and brings prosperity.
It is 3.8 kilometers South-East of Varanasi Junction railway station
